I.  THE PROPOSAL 
 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed senior 
secured debt financing of up to $50,000,000 (in Indian rupee equivalent) through nonconvertible 
debentures (NCDs) to be issued by Northern Arc Capital Limited (NACL) for the Northern Arc 
COVID-19 Livelihood Support Project in India. 
 
2.  NACL is a nonbank financial company (NBFC), which is a pioneer in the finance sector in 
India, first connecting microfinance institutions (MFIs) and now other NBFCs to mainstream 
financiers through a variety of products, such as partial risk guarantees for capital market 
issuances. NACL also lends directly to certain customer segments that have traditionally had 
limited access to finance. The debt financing of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) will support 
NACL’s  plan  to  restart  its  funding  and  guarantees,  which  came  to  a  standstill  during  the 
coronavirus disease (COVID-19) pandemic lockdown, and will target individual micro borrowers; 
micro-,  small-,  and  medium-sized  enterprises  (MSMEs);  and  home  loan  borrowers.  These 
customer segments have been particularly impacted by COVID-19. NACL will lend directly to 
them and provide support to financiers lending to these segments by catalyzing private debt from 
banks,  international  financial  institutions,  and  local  capital  markets.  As  a  result  of  ADB’s 
intervention, NACL will implement measures under a gender action plan (GAP) to expand access 
to credit for women. 
 
II.  THE FINANCIAL INTERMEDIARY 
 
A.  Investment Identification and Description 
 
3.  Constrained access to finance for individuals and micro, small, and medium-sized 
enterprises. About 190 million Indian adults still do not have a bank account despite account 
ownership greatly increasing from 35% in 2011 to 80% in 2017.1 Less than 6.6% of borrowers 
access credit through formal channels.2 In fiscal year (FY) 2017, India had an estimated 55.8 
million (nonagricultural) MSMEs operating in the top-five industries: retail (46.0%), food products 
and  beverages  (6.0%),  apparel  (5.0%),  motor  vehicle  repair  (4.0%),  and  textiles  (3.0%).3 
Predominantly unregistered, 94.9% of MSMEs were micro-, 4.9% small-, and 0.2% medium-sized 
enterprises.4 MSMEs accounted for about 31% of gross domestic product (GDP) and 45% of 
exports, and employed more than 124 million people. About 59.5% of MSMEs are in rural and 
40.5% in urban areas. The lack of adequate access to finance is a major obstacle to growth of 
MSMEs, with 84% self-financing or using informal finance sources and only 16% accessing credit 
from formal financial institutions. For women who own businesses, the issue is more acute, with 
more than 90% of their finance requirements being met through informal sources. The reasons 
include limited awareness and understanding of financial products because of women’s lack of 
financial education and unfamiliarity with formal banking institutions, lack of collateral to guarantee 
credit, and difficulty in presenting their personal profiles and track records. Women also require 
support from male family members for loan applications and are subjected to other discriminatory 
 
1  Global Findex Database. 2017. Measuring Financial Inclusion and the Fintech Revolution. Washington, DC: World 
Bank Group. The number of unbanked people declined dramatically after the government launched the Pradhan 
Mantri Jan Dhan Yojana scheme, under which 404.1 million bank accounts were opened as of 26 August 2020. 
2  World Bank. Global Findex Database (accessed 26 July 2020). Of the people who borrowed money in the 12 months 
before the survey (survey carried out in 2017), 14% borrowed through a formal channel, 72% through family and 
friends, and the rest via private money lenders. 
3  International Finance Corporation. 2018. Financing India’s MSMEs: Estimation of Debt Requirement of MSMEs in 
India. Washington, DC. 
4  Only 15% of MSMEs are registered as enterprises with district industry centers or the online Udyog Aadhaar system.

2 
practices by loan officers.5 Access to long-term, larger loans, such as mortgages, are particularly 
problematic.6 
 
4.  Nonbank financial companies at the forefront of financial inclusion. As of the end of 
March 2020, 9,601 NBFCs were registered7 but only 278 were considered systemically important 
by the regulator, the Reserve Bank of India (RBI).8 State-owned banks, which have traditionally 
dominated the banking landscape, continue to focus on direct agriculture loans and collateral-
backed loans to MSMEs, allowing NBFCs to flourish, with their share of total credit rising sharply 
from 18% in FY2015 to 23% in FY2019. NBFCs have created a business niche in inclusive 
sectors, targeting lower-income segments, where banks have limited or negligible presence. 
NBFCs often rely on alternative credit lending models, such as assessing cash flows for informal 
businesses or relying on the social contract that exists in close-knit communities rather than 
traditional collateral-backed lending models. NBFCs have reached underserved and unserved 
customers by establishing superior low-cost distribution models. Banks have also started relying 
on NBFCs to support lower-income segments, lending to which qualifies as priority sector lending 
(PSL),9 by (i) purchasing portfolios originated by NBFCs through the securitization and direct 
assignment route,10 (ii) partnering with them through the business correspondent route,11 and 
(iii) entering into co-lending arrangements.12 The success of the NBFC business model can be 
gauged from the conversion, in 2016, of nine NBFCs into small finance banks (SFBs), a special 
bank category created by RBI to assist the underserved and unserved segments. Housing finance 
companies (HFCs) primarily target special customer segments (often outside urban areas), 
including affordable housing buyers and the self-employed, whom commercial banks do not 
serve. As of March 2020, HFCs accounted for 34% of the total mortgage loan market.13 
 
5.  Constraints  in  raising  debt.  Access  to  medium-  and  long-term  finance  is  highly 
constrained for NBFCs, especially small and medium-sized ones. Typically, the only formal 
sources of funding available to such NBFCs are domestic bank loans and, selectively, finance 
from multilateral development banks and development finance institutions for the larger, higher-
rated NBFCs. Even then, the quantum of funding is often restricted because of the limited track 
record,  small  size,  and  lower  credit  ratings  of  many  NBFCs.  India’s  bond  markets  have 
 
5  ADB. 2014. Gender Tool Kit: Micro, Small, and Medium-Sized Enterprise Finance and Development. Manila. 
6  India has low mortgage penetration (10.3%) and a shortage of housing units, last estimated at 18.7 million in urban 
and 43.7 million in rural areas. An estimated 90% of the shortage is in the affordable housing segment, primarily for 
the economically weaker section and the low-income group. ICRA Research. 2020. Indian Mortgage Finance Market. 
August 2020. Delhi; Ministry of Housing and Urban Poverty Alleviation. 2017. Pradhan Mantri Awas Yojna. Delhi. 
According to the ministry, those in the economically weaker section have a family income of less than ₹0.3 million 
per annum; in the low-income group, ₹0.3 million–₹0.6 million; and in the middle-income group, more than ₹0.6 
million and less than ₹1.8 million. 
7  In this document, NBFCs include MFIs and housing finance companies (HFCs) unless specified. 
8  Those with total assets of more than ₹5 billion. 
9  PSL is a requirement of RBI to support financial inclusion. As per current guidelines, commercial banks must lend at

estimated ₹2.0 trillion in FY2020, nearly triple the ₹692.0 billion in FY2016.

deposits, accepting remittances, making remittance payouts, and originating loans on behalf of the bank. 
12 Customer origination, collection, and servicing are done by the NBFC while typically retaining 20% of a loan on its 
balance sheet, with the balance booked by the partner bank. Co-lending is expected to increase. 
13 ICRA Research. 2020. Indian Mortgage Finance Market. August 2020. Delhi.

3 
traditionally catered to government entities and large top-rated corporates and thus have limited 
depth. As a result, most small and medium-sized NBFCs do not access the bond markets, 
especially for medium- and long-term paper. NBFCs that focus on financially inclusive sectors are 
often small, which limits their access to medium- and long-term bank funding and to debt capital 
markets. 
 
6.  Access to debt funding has been further constrained since the collapse, in September 
2018, of Infrastructure Leasing and Financial Services Limited (IL&FS),14 a large and well-known 
NBFC, as well as certain other NBFCs. The mutual fund industry’s exposure to NBFCs decreased 
sharply by 48% from July 2018 to July 2020.15 Banks bridged part of the gap, with lending to 
NBFCs as a percentage of total bank credit rising from 7.0% in October 2018 to 9.0% in June 
2020.16 The same was not adequate, however, to prevent a slowdown in credit growth in the 
NBFC sector, which saw its annual growth of 17.7% in FY2014–FY2018 fall to an estimated 
11.3% in FY2018–FY2020. By comparison, bank credit growth was 6.7% in FY2014–FY2018 and 
12.0% in FY2018–FY2020. 
 
7.  COVID-19 impact. The Government of India responded to the COVID-19 pandemic by 
imposing one of the most stringent lockdowns, starting 24 March 2020, before easing some 
restrictions in May 2020 and easing them further in June 2020.17 The lockdowns halted business 
operations and mobility during April and May 2020, which not only impacted businesses but also 
resulted in increasing loss of livelihoods, primarily in the lower-income segment. As a result, 
India’s GDP is expected to contract by 9.0% in FY2021.18 NBFCs and their customers have been 
heavily impacted by COVID-19. Most NBFC clients, who are largely in the informal segment, were 
(and, in certain locations, still are) affected by lockdowns. The effect of the pandemic and the 
resulting lockdowns was evident in the loan moratoriums availed by customers to conserve 
liquidity and tide them over during the shortfall of cash flows. As per NACL estimates, in April and 
May 2020, NBFCs extended moratoriums to ~95% of micro borrowers, ~70% of MSMEs, and 
~35% of affordable housing customers. CRISIL estimates revenues for MSMEs to reduce by 
17%–21% and earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation, and amortization margins to decline 
by 30%–40% in FY2021.19 A slow recovery cycle because of extended or rolling lockdowns, 
coupled  with  limited  credit  and  weakening  demand,  worsened  the  credit  profiles  of  these 
customers. NBFCs’ ability to extend moratoriums allowed by RBI was compromised because they 
did not get a moratorium from all their lenders thus adversely impacting the NBFCs’ liquidity 
position.20 The flow of fresh credit to the sector, especially to the lower-rated NBFCs, was curtailed 
 
14 IL&FS, a AAA-rated NBFC, defaulted on its payment obligations, driven by asset–liability mismatches, with short-
term funding supporting the development of long-gestation infrastructure projects. The default caused a crisis of 
confidence among capital market investors, leading to a liquidity crunch for NBFCs. Dewan Housing Finance 
Corporation, one of the largest HFCs in India, defaulted on its payments in June 2019. It had significant exposure to 
real estate companies, which were in the middle of a prolonged slowdown and heavily dependent on short-term 
commercial paper, which contributed to liquidity issues. In September 2019, Altico, an NBFC focused on real estate 
financing, defaulted because of large-ticket exposures to the troubled real estate developer segment and asset–
liability mismatches.

18 ADB. 2020. Asian Development Outlook 2020 Update: Wellness in Worrying Times September 2020. Manila.

20 RBI allowed banks and NBFCs to extend a moratorium to their clients for 3 months, from March to June 2020. During 
this cycle, NBFCs, which are largely funded by banks and mostly non-deposit taking, received on average a

after which it allowed banks and NBFCs to offer a one-time restructuring of loans for businesses and/or individuals 
afflicted by the pandemic.

4 
despite some targeted government interventions.21 In its annual financial stability report of July 
2020, RBI expressed concern about the declining share of market funding for NBFCs, especially 
smaller and medium-sized ones, which had not been supported by banks and the capital markets. 
RBI felt that this situation could accentuate the liquidity risk for the sector and the financial system. 
Because of the expected slowdown in funding, the NBFC sector is expected to experience a 50%–
60% decline in disbursements and its first fall in assets under management (AUMs) in nearly 2 
decades, with negative growth of 1%–3% in FY2021. 22 
 
8.  Lessons. The project draws on the experience of previous ADB loans to NBFCs and MFIs 
in India, as well as lessons from support to MSMEs during times of crisis.23 These lessons include 
the following: (i) a timely and relevant response is needed (ADB supported the NBFC and MFI 
sector after demonetization in November 2016 and the IL&FS-linked challenges in September 
2018); (ii) local currency loans should be provided; and (iii) amortizing loans, which align with the 
client’s underlying cash flows, are preferable to bullet loan structures, to reduce asset–liability 
mismatches and refinancing risk for the company. 
 
9.  Rationale. Underserved segments’ access to finance, particularly during the pandemic, 
remains a problem. NACL, with its deep understanding of NBFCs and India’s capital markets and 
strong  originating  capabilities,  coupled  with  its  sound  risk  culture  and  innovative  product 
development capabilities, is a suitable candidate for ADB funding. NACL has been a partner in 
ADB’s Microfinance Risk Participation and Guarantee Program since 2011.24 NACL is a pioneer 
in the capital markets, facilitating access to mainstream finance for MFIs through innovative risk-
sharing structures. Initially, NACL facilitated financing to the microfinance segment as a strategy 
for banks to meet PSL requirements. Over the years, however, NACL has expanded its support 
to other inclusive asset classes by offering MSME, vehicle, agriculture, and affordable housing 
financing,  among  others,  primarily  for  smaller  and  lower-rated  NBFCs.  NACL  also  started 
providing direct loans to MSMEs and individuals for business purposes along with some personal 
loans. The direct loans are either originated by NACL (in the case of smaller corporates and 
medium-sized enterprises) or through its NBFC partners, where NACL co-finances each exposure 
and thus takes the underlying credit risk  (in the case of micro and small enterprises and 
individuals). More than 90% of total business volumes25 raised by NACL support the livelihood of 
customers, i.e., loans are for productive purposes. From its inception to the end of March 2020, 
NACL has raised funding of close to $12.0 billion to the inclusive finance sector. Given its 
successful track record in limiting nonperforming loans (NPLs) in wholesale lending portfolios, 
NACL witnessed increased demand from other investors that did not have PSL requirements, 
such as impact funds, mutual funds, insurance companies, and foreign institutional investors.

of India; 20% first-loss guarantee for purchasing NBFC paper; guarantee cover to support onlending by banks and 
NBFCs to existing MSME customers, among others.

10.  ADB’s funding is important to support much-needed access to long-term and stable debt 
funding to NACL given COVID-19’s impacts on the market and NBFCs’ client base. NACL 
extended moratoriums to a large portion of its NBFC clients in April and May 2020 to allow them 
to cope with requests for moratoriums from their customers during the complete lockdown. As 
lockdowns started easing in June, moratorium requirements reduced, but still there were demand 
for moratorium from significant number of clients. The moratoriums ended in August 2020. The 
transaction will support plans of NACL to restart guarantee operations and disbursements to its 
clients. The support will address a key concern of smaller NBFCs, which is access to fresh credit, 
and allow them to lend to their customers in highly affected segments such as microfinance and 
MSME financing. Given NACL’s business model, the transaction is expected to catalyze domestic 
and foreign capital financing for these inclusive segments. 
 
11.  NACL is well placed to mitigate some of COVID-19’s impacts despite a large share of its 
portfolio being affected by the pandemic. The company has a strong capital adequacy ratio, which 
is expected to absorb possible increases in credit costs as per stress tests conducted by ADB. 
Similarly, the company has maintained good liquidity buffers. Fresh debt funding from ADB will 
allow NACL to further boost its liquidity profile and allow it to increase disbursements to and 
guarantees for its clients, helping them recover faster. 
 
B.  Business Overview and Strategy 
 
12.  Overview. NACL was established as IFMR Capital Limited in 2008 by Dvara Trust 
(erstwhile IFMR Trust), a not-for-profit foundation focused on financial inclusion. NACL was 
founded to connect high-quality NBFCs with potential investors for debt fundraising, to enable 
them to deepen their presence and improve the access of millions of financially excluded 
households in India to financial services. NACL has become a market-leading debt platform for 
NBFCs with a presence in 680 districts in 29 states and 5 union territories through its 242 partner 
originators,  serving  more  than  33  million  underlying  borrowers  as  of  FY2020.  NACL  has 
developed its expertise across sectors and a variety of products over the years. NACL acts as an 
intermediary between originators, which cater to financially excluded households and enterprises 
across the country, and debt capital market investors by providing direct loans and by undertaking 
structured transactions where NACL subscribes to a junior tranche (higher risk)26 or takes a 
second loss position in transactions that it originates for its clients. Such a structure often 
strengthens the credit rating of the senior tranche, thus attracting mainstream financial investors. 
The company, in effect, is a wholesale lender and provides debt financing to NBFCs through a 
combination of its own balance sheet lending, syndications, securitizations, and guarantees. The 
business volumes managed by NACL include all the fund raising it has arranged for its clients, 
while NACL’s balance sheet exposure forms part of its  assets under management. NACL 
manages an alternate investment fund investing in structured debt issued by financial service 
companies through its 100% subsidiary, Northern Arc Investment Managers.  
 
13.  Business strategy. NACL plans to continue using its strong risk management capability 
to retain its core focus as a debt platform for NBFCs. The company also plans to make its 
exposures  more  granular  by  expanding  its  partnership  model  for  supporting  MSMEs  and 
consumer lending businesses, while moving into new sectors such as gold loans. The total direct 
origination portfolio, through co-lending with partner financial institutions, including the MSME 
segment, is expected to grow faster than the rest of the business and increase its contribution. 
The company has established strong technology infrastructure to monitor and integrate the direct 
lending portfolio with its partner originators.

C.  Ownership, Management, and Governance 
 
14.  Ownership.27 ADB  conducted  integrity  due  diligence  on  NACL,  its  managers  and 
shareholders,  and  their  fund  managers  and  shareholders. 28  NACL’s  shareholders  are 
predominantly institutional investors, private equity funds, trusts, and a foundation.  
 
15.  Corporate governance. NACL’s board of directors is responsible for providing strategic 
direction,  setting  policies,  supervising  the  company’s  performance,  and  ensuring  NACL’s 
compliance with laws and regulations. NACL has a strong board with eminent and reputable 
members, each with decades of experience in financial services. In accordance with applicable 
regulatory guidelines, 36% of the board is represented by four independent board members. The 
other seven members include nominee directors of the shareholders and the managing director 
and chief executive officer of the company. The board has various committees, including for audit, 
remuneration, corporate social responsibility, and risk, which govern NACL’s functions. 
 
16.  Management.  Kshama  Fernandes,  a  risk  professional  with  more  than  20  years  of 
experience in financial services, consulting, and academia, heads a team of 227 people. She was 
previously the chief risk officer of NACL. She is supported by Nandita Ganapathy, chief financial 
officer, with more than 20 years of experience; Bama Balakrishnan, chief operating officer, with 
more than 20 years of experience; and Pardhasaradhi Rallabandi, chief risk officer, with more 
than 20 years of experience in organizations such as Standard Chartered and IDBI Bank. 
 
17.  Risk management. NACL has a strong risk culture as can be seen from its near-zero 
delinquency track record in its direct wholesale lending portfolio. NACL follows an integrated risk 
management approach to evaluate the complete credit cycle, from onboarding to monitoring, 
making extensive use of analytics and modeling to measure macro-, sector-, and company-
specific trends. Any new segment undergoes 12–18 months of evaluation with two or three clients, 
with  the  board  having  final  responsibility  for  approving  the  onboarding.  The  board’s  risk 
management committee meets every quarter to review the portfolio, sets exposure limits for each 
client, and is responsible for setting policy. The chief risk officer directly reports to the committee. 
As a response to various crisis impacting the NBFC sector, NACL adopted stricter changes in its 
exposure limits and governance monitoring of portfolio entities. 
 
D.  Confidential Information Deleted  
   
III.  THE PROPOSED ADB ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  The Assistance 
 
18.  ADB will provide a senior secured debt financing of up to $50 million (in rupee equivalent) 
to NACL at a tenor of up to 5 years by subscribing to NCDs.29  
   
 
27 For details on ownership, board of directors, senior management, and risk management, please refer to Ownership, 
Management, and Governance (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2). 
28 ADB. 2003. Enhancing the Asian Development Bank's Role in Combating Money Laundering and the Financing of 
Terrorism. Manila; and Integrity Due Diligence Disclosure (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 
2). 
29 An NCD is a form of fixed-maturity debt security regulated by RBI and SEBI. Upon issuance, the NCD will be listed 
on the Bombay Stock Exchange or National Stock Exchange. If a regulatory change makes it unfeasible to structure 
the financing as an NCD issuance, ADB may provide a bilateral loan to NACL on substantially the same terms.

7 
B.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
19.  Use of proceeds. NACL will use the proceeds of the ADB financing to fund or provide 
guarantees to its NBFC and SFB clients, microfinance borrowers, and MSMEs. A small part of 
ADB’s proceeds will be used to provide housing loans to the economically weaker section and 
low-income group. 
 
20.  Reporting arrangements. ADB will monitor the project throughout its duration.30 NACL 
will submit to ADB (i) quarterly unaudited financial statements, (ii) annual audited financial 
statements, (iii) quarterly loan portfolio and covenant reports, (iv) annual development indicators 
agreed  between  ADB  and  NACL,  (v)  annual  reports  on  safeguards  and  social  protection 
compliance, and (vi) annual progress reports on the GAP implementation. 
 
C.  Value Added by ADB Assistance 
 
21.  Supporting livelihoods. The transaction will support NACL’s funding and guarantee 
activities for the inclusive finance sector,31 thus facilitating the flow of credit to MSMEs and 
microfinance borrowers adversely affected by COVID-19 and allowing them to restart their 
operations. Crucially, the transaction will catalyze funding to the sector from private investors. 
NACL’s typical ratio of business volume to on–balance sheet exposure is five times (i.e., NACL 
enables a significantly higher amount of credit flow for its clients for every dollar it provides 
directly). The funding from ADB to NACL is likely to give a positive signal to other lenders and, 
thus, catalyze additional funding for the company. 
 
22.  Providing access to longer tenor funding. By providing long-tenor financing, ADB will 
help NACL support longer-tenor asset classes such as affordable housing and MSME loans. More 
importantly, ADB will provide a source of stable long-term funding, which is especially difficult to 
raise given market events since September 2018. ADB funding will allow NACL to offer longer-
tenor financing to its NBFC and SFB clients, which is not readily available through India’s bond 
markets, especially after the onset of COVID-19. 
 
23.  Helping develop capital markets. The transaction will support the issuance of debt 
capital by small and medium-sized NBFCs by aiding the overall growth of NACL’s operations. 
NACL has diversified the investor base for its inclusive finance clients, which has helped broaden 
capital markets. ADB’s support will help NACL continue expanding its innovative products and 
structures, thereby crowding in private capital for the growth of the inclusive finance space. 
 
24.  Promoting  women’s  entrepreneurship.  As  part  of  ADB’s  intervention,  the  gender 
measures for NACL include developing and using a gender equality scorecard to evaluate the 
gender equality actions of new institutional clients, the outputs of which may be used for an annual 
workshop  with  institutional  clients  to  increase  gender  equality.  The  GAP  includes  NACL 
increasing the proportion of loans of its MSME financiers that go to women borrowers or co-
borrowers. 
   
 
30 Details of Implementation Arrangements (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2). 
31 NACL may be required to put up cash collateral, which can be funded from ADB’s proceeds, to provide guarantee 
support to its clients.

8 
D.  Confidential Information Deleted 
   
IV.  DEVELOPMENT IMPACT AND STRATEGIC ALIGNMENT 
 
A.  Development Impact, Outcome, and Outputs 
 
25.  Impact. The project is aligned with the Government of India’s COVID-19 Response 
Stimulus Package to bank and nonbank financial institutions.32 
 
26.  Outcome. The project will have the following outcome: NACL’s support to financially 
inclusive institutions and MSMEs in India increased.33 
 
27.  Outputs. The outputs will be to expand NACL’s funding capacity for lending to and 
facilitating financing for financially inclusive institutions in India; and enhance gender equality 
within NACL and for its clients. 
 
B.  Alignment with ADB Strategy and Operations 
 
28.  The  project  will  contribute to  the following  operational  priorities  of  Strategy  2030:34 
(i) tackling remaining poverty and reducing inequalities and (ii) accelerating progress in gender 
equality.  According  to  ADB’s  country  partnership  strategy  for  India,  2018–2022,  ADB’s 
nonsovereign operations will continue to support the development of the finance sector.35 The 
proposed transaction will support the development of MSMEs, increasing financial inclusion and 
aiding  affordable  housing  finance,  which  are  key  in  the  country  partnership  strategy,  and 
strengthening the COVID-19 pandemic response.36 The project is consistent with the Strategy for 
New India @ 75, the Government of India’s defined objectives for FY2023, which indicates 
financial inclusion, Housing for All, and employment as drivers of economic growth.37 The project 
is aligned with ADB’s Gender Equality and Women’s Empowerment Operational Plan, 2013–
2020.38 
 
V.  POLICY COMPLIANCE 
 
A.  Safeguards and Social Dimensions 
 
29.  ADB has categorized the debt investment as category FI (treated as C) for environment, 
involuntary resettlement, and indigenous peoples, in compliance with ADB’s Safeguard Policy 
Statement (2009). 
 
 
32 On 16 May 2020, the Government of India announced an economic stimulus package of ₹20 trillion (about 10% of 
GDP) under the Atma Nirbhar Bharat Abhiyan (Self-Reliant India Scheme), which includes ₹3 trillion support to 
businesses, including MSMEs; a ₹300 billion special liquidity facility for NBFCs, HFCs, and MFIs. Government of 
India Portal. 2020. Major Announcements and Policy Reforms under Aatma Nirbhar Bharat Abhiyan. 25 May; and 
Government of India, Press Information Bureau. 2020. Finance Minister Announces New Horizons of Growth; 
Structural Reforms Across Eight Sectors Paving Way for Aatma Nirbhar Bharat. Delhi (16 May). 
33 Includes MFI, SFB, and NBFC financing loans to MSMEs and affordable housing. 
34 ADB. 2018. Strategy 2030: Achieving a Prosperous, Inclusive, Resilient, and Sustainable Asia and the Pacific. 
Manila. 
35 ADB. 2017. Country Partnership Strategy: India, 2018–2022—Accelerating Inclusive Economic Transformation. 
Manila. 
36 ADB. 2020. Report and Recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors: Proposed Modalities to India 
for COVID-19 Active Response and Expenditure Support Program. Manila. 
37 Government of India, NITI Aayog. 2018. Strategy for New India @ 75. New Delhi. 
38 ADB. 2013. Gender Equality and Women’s Empowerment Operational Plan, 2013–2020: Moving the Agenda 
Forward in Asia and the Pacific. Manila.

9 
30.  NACL’s business activities have minimal or no adverse environmental impacts and are 
unlikely to affect involuntary resettlement and indigenous peoples. The potential environmental 
and social effects and associated risks of the debt investment, and NACL’s commitment and 
capacity for environmental and social management were assessed. NACL has an environmental, 
social, and governance (ESG) policy and a responsible-investment code, which are applied to all 
NACL investments. During due diligence, ADB identified the following actions to strengthen 
NACL’s  environmental  and  social  management  system  to  meet  ADB’s  Safeguard  Policy 
Statement requirements: (i) adopt ADB's prohibited investment activities list in NACL’s ESG 
policy; (ii) screen subprojects, and if they are in category A and category B for the environment, 
involuntary resettlement, and indigenous peoples, make them ineligible to use ADB proceeds; 
(iii) ensure that investments using ADB funds comply with ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement and 
abide by applicable national laws and regulations, including labor laws, pursuant to ADB’s Social 
Protection Strategy; (iv) take measures to comply with international core labor standards; and (v) 
adopt these changes as a supplementary environmental and social plan of the ESG policy before 
disbursement of funds.39 NACL will submit periodic reports to ADB to confirm the environmental 
and social impacts of ADB-funded NBFCs and MSMEs and their compliance with local and 
national environmental, health and safety, and labor regulations and standards (footnote 41). The 
climate change impact from the project is expected to be low because of the nature and scale of 
loans that may be financed by the ADB loan proceeds. 
 
31.  Effective gender mainstreaming. In 2016, 90% of women entrepreneurs surveyed had 
not availed themselves of finance from formal institutional channels, and an estimated 70% or 
₹1.4 trillion of financing demand remained unmet.40 Nearly 3 million MSMEs are fully or partially 
owned by women, and about 78% are in services, which have been particularly hard hit by the 
COVID-19 crisis.41 NACL is a pioneer in enabling finance to NBFCs that lend predominantly to 
women. Following ADB’s Policy on Gender and Development (1998), NACL will commit to 
incorporate measures to promote gender equality and women’s empowerment in its business 
activities. Confidential information deleted. NACL will submit periodic reports on implementation 
of gender measures to ADB. 
 
B.  Anticorruption Policy 
 
32.  NACL was advised of ADB’s policy of implementing best international practice relating to 
combating corruption, money laundering, and the financing of terrorism. ADB will ensure that the 
investment documentation includes provisions prohibiting corruption, money laundering, and the 
financing of terrorism, and remedies for ADB in the event of noncompliance. 
 
C.  Confidential Information Deleted 
 
D.  Assurances 
 
33.  Consistent with the Agreement Establishing the Asian Development Bank (the Charter),42 
ADB will proceed with the proposed assistance upon establishing that the Government of India 
has no objection to the proposed assistance to NACL.43 ADB will enter into suitable finance 
documentation, in form and substance satisfactory to ADB, following approval of the proposed 
assistance by the ADB Board of Directors. 
 
39 Summary Poverty Reduction and Social Strategy (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2). 
40 International Finance Corporation. 2016. Financial Inclusion for Women-Owned MSMEs in India. New Delhi. 
41 UN Women. 2020. Unlocking the Lockdown: The Gendered Effects of COVID-19 on Achieving the SDGs in Asia and 
the Pacific. New York. 
42 ADB. 1966. Agreement Establishing the Asian Development Bank. Manila. 
43 Government no-objection should be established well in advance of seeking Board approval, in accordance with the 
procedure outlined in the Department of Economic Affairs circular dated 27 June 2016, para. 4 II (ii).

10 
VI.  RECOMMENDATION 
 
34.  I am satisfied that the proposed debt investment would comply with the Articles of 
Agreement of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) and recommend that the Board approve the 
proposed senior secured debt financing of up to $50,000,000 (in Indian rupee equivalent), through 
nonconvertible debentures from ADB’s ordinary capital resources to Northern Arc Capital Limited 
for the Northern Arc COVID-19 Livelihood Support Project in India, with such terms and conditions 
as are substantially in accordance with those set forth in this report, and as may be reported to 
the Board. 
 
Masatsugu Asakawa 
President 
 
16 October 2020
